We take pride in strictly following the "Ayurvedic shastras" Ayurveda is one of the world's oldest medical systems and has been practiced in India for thousands of years. It is based on the belief that health and wellness depend on a delicate balance between the mind, body, and spirit. One of the key principles of Ayurveda is the concept of the three doshas, which are the fundamental energies that govern the body. These are Vata, Pitta, and Kapha. Each person has a unique combination of these doshas, and imbalances in any one of them can lead to health problems. An Ayurvedic practitioner will take into account a person's individual dosha balance when formulating a treatment plan. Herbs are an important aspect of Ayurvedic medicine. Ayurvedic practitioners use herbs to help balance the doshas, improve digestion, and support overall health. Some common Ayurvedic herbs include turmeric, ginger, [ashwagandha](https://drdassans.com/product/ashwagandha-tablets), and [neem](https://drdassans.com/product/neem-tablets). These herbs can be taken in the form of teas, capsules, or as ingredient in oil form for massage. Ayurveda places a strong emphasis on diet and nutrition as a way to maintain health and prevent disease. According to Ayurveda, certain foods are believed to aggravate the doshas and should be avoided, while others are believed to balance them and should be consumed regularly. An Ayurvedic practitioner may recommend a specific diet based on a person's individual dosha balance.Yoga and Meditation Yoga and meditation are important components of Ayurveda. They are believed to help balance the doshas, improve overall health and well-being, and promote a sense of calm and balance.
